Elaborating on the Ministryâ€™s three-pronged strategy, Minister for Manpower, Josephine Teo, emphasised that safety distancing measures have been heightened in foreign worker dormitories to actively contain the spread. In the first prong, dormitories with existing clusters will be locked down and the movement of workers within the dormitories will be restricted. In the second prong, these safety distancing measures will also be applied to dormitories with no clusters to further prevent the spread of the COVID-19 infection. Lastly, workers in essential services have been placed in separate housing facilities instead of dormitories and have undergone medical screenings to ensure that they did not have symptoms before moving into alternative accommodation.
She was speaking at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce press conference on 14 April 2020.

Video: MEDIACORP

Minister for Manpower, Josephine Teo, spoke at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce press conference on 14 April 2020 about the three key enablers which the Ministry engaged to manage the spread of COVID-19 in dormitories. Minister Teo highlighted the role of the three groups of people â€” FAST teams, medical outposts, dormitory operators and employers - to ensure that safe distancing measures are implemented effectively.

Video: MEDIACORP

Associate Professor Kenneth Mak, Director of Medical Services, provided a situational update on 14 April 2020 at the Multi-Ministry Taskforceâ€™s press conference.

Video: MEDIACORP

At the Multi-Ministry Taskforce Conference on 14 April 2020, Minister for National Development, Lawrence Wong, announced that the Government will tighten current measures by making it mandatory for everyone to wear a mask when they go out. Children under the age of two are exempted from this new rule due to concerns over child safety. Those participating in strenuous exercises such as jogging or running are also allowed to remove their masks temporarily when engaging in such activities. He stressed that the Government will continue to take strict action against those who breach the circuit breaker measures. The first offense will incur a fine of $300 and the second offense $1000 or prosecution in court.

So this year, while we canâ€™t celebrate the new year together in person, we will do so in spirit!

In particular, I invite all Singaporeans to join me in wishing our foreign worker friends, many of whom are confined to their dorms and unable to go out for celebrations, a very Happy New Year too! Charities, social service agencies and ground-up groups can approach the National Council of Social Service, if they need to be whitelisted to provide essential aid, such as food and financial support to vulnerable groups.

Desmond Lee
13 April 2020 at 15:16 Â·

We have received many queries from good-hearted charities, social service agencies and ground-up groups whether they can continue community service outreach during the Circuit Breaker.

During this period, we want to ensure that vulnerable people continue to get essential support. At the same time, all of us need to stay home, reduce our social interactions to the minimum, and go out when absolutely necessary. Only then can we reduce the spread of COVID-19.

To strike a sensible balance, charities, social service agencies and ground-up groups can approach the National Council of Social Service if they need their activities that provide essential aid, such as food and financial support, to be whitelisted. NCSS will coordinate and work with you to ensure that our vulnerable get support during the Circuit Breaker, while ensuring that they are kept safe and your volunteers and staff achieve stringent safe distancing. Some activities must continue, others can be modified or temporarily suspended.

Meanwhile, essential social services by MSF (e.g. our SSOs, residential homes, designated community services providing critical care) will continue to serve our most vulnerable among us.

Let's work together to help our most vulnerable get through this crisis. If you come across someone in the community who needs assistance, please contact the ComCare Hotline at 1800-222-0000.

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether #SGCares

#notsuredontshare #factually

https://www.facebook.com/singaporepoliceforce/posts/10159691515574408

MEWR.GOV.SG
Safe Distancing Measures in Public Spaces in HDB Estates

Singapore Police Force
13 April 2020 at 21:35 Â·

[POLICE DO NOT CONDUCT ROAD BLOCKS TO ENFORCE ELEVATED SAFE DISTANCING MEASURES]

There are messages circulating via text messaging services making false claims that members of the public had been stopped at police road blocks and fined for not complying with the elevated safe distancing measures. This is not true. The Police have not conducted road blocks specifically to enforce the elevated safe distancing measures, and no passengers have been fined at road blocks for not complying with these measures.

The Police conduct road blocks to detect offences such as for drink-driving, and other law enforcement purposes, such as to detect wanted persons. Nevertheless, if the Police come across motorists and passengers flouting the elevated safe distancing measures when conducting such road blocks, the Police may take enforcement action.

The Police urge the public not to spread unsubstantiated information which may cause public alarm.

Visit the MEWR website for the latest information on safe distancing measures: http://mewr.gov.sg/safe-distancing.

A two-pronged strategy will be deployed to combat the outbreak of COVID-19 in foreign worker dormitories in Singapore, said Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong at a Multi-Ministry Taskforce Press Conference on 9 April 2020.

Firstly, Government officers will be deployed to the dorms to provide for the daily needs of workers and to ensure hygiene, cleanliness and safe distancing standards.

Secondly, Medical posts will be set up in the dorms to screen for infections, and to separate healthy workers from ones who are sick. Healthy workers working in essential services will also be moved to alternative sites, like vacant hdb blocks and floating hotels, so that safe distancing measures can be better enforced in dormitories.

Stadiums in Singapore will now be closed, announced Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong, as part of stricter Circuit Breaker measures designed to slow down the spread of COVID-19. The move comes after numerous congregational hotspots were still observed since the start of Circuit Breaker, despite the Governmentâ€™s instructions to avoid gathering in groups or leaving the house unnecessarily. He added that Circuit Breaker measures will be reviewed continuously and stepped up further, should cases of non-compliance persist.

Minister Lawrence Wong was speaking at a Multi-Ministry Taskforce Press Conference on 9 April 2020.

Seniors are a particularly vulnerable group whose safety will require the cooperation of everyone, said Minister of Health Gan Kim Yong at a Multi-Ministry Taskforce Press Conference on 9 April 2020. Parents should avoid dropping their children off with grandparents if they have to go to work in essential services, and should only visit the elderly if absolutely necessary, and only for short periods of time. He also appealed to Singaporeans to avoid travelling or leaving their homes this long weekend, and to maintain Circuit Breaker and safe distancing measures, so as to avoid exposing the more vulnerable to infection.
Associate Professor Kenneth Mak, Director of Medical Services, provided a situational update on 9 April 2020 at the Multi-Ministry Taskforceâ€™s press conference.

S Iswaran
9 April 2020 at 07:01 Â·

Reaching out to Singaporeans in more ways than one.

In a situation like this COVID-19 outbreak, we need to broaden access to information across as many platforms as possible to reach everyone with reliable, clear and timely information.

We have been doing our best to keep you informed about the rapidly evolving COVID-19 situation through many platforms - digitally, like Gov.sg website, Gov.sg WhatsApp, Telegram and Twitter, and traditionally, through newspaper and television ads.

To complement these efforts, we are now launching the COVID-19 Info Bot, that will give you quick answers to topical questions and concerns. The COVID-19 Info Bot is accessible on the Gov.sg website or by visiting www.gov.sg/infobot, and will help you navigate through all the information.

The information on this Info Bot is tailored to specific groups â€“ for students, parents, businesses and employers, and workers. It will carry summarised information relating to COVID-19 from various government agencies, ranging from mask distribution, home-based learning for students, workplace closures, advisories on good hygiene practices, being socially responsible and more!

Share this COVID-19 Info Bot with your loved ones and friends. Together, letâ€™s keep each other informed and keep one another safe!

Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR)
5 April 2020 at 17:00 Â·

When the COVID-19 outbreak began, A*STAR tasked our researchers and engineers to channel their focus towards coming up with innovations that would contribute to Singaporeâ€™s fight against #COVID19.

These have included work on diagnostic test kits, therapeutics, in-silico modelling, and the employment of computer vision and deep learning to detect lung infection on chest x-rays, among others.

One ground-up initiative that has emerged is that of a DIY mask, the result of brainstorming from student researchers.

The DIY mask can be easily assembled using everyday items. This is timely, and will support the ongoing safe distancing measures.

We hope this video will be of help to all Singaporeans. Stay safe, everyone!

#FakeNewsAlert This text message is false. The Police have not receive any reports regarding such incidents.

#StayCalm #StayAlert Do not spread or forward false information.

Singapore Police Force
4 April 2020 at 10:35 Â·

FALSE MESSAGE CIRCULATING IN THE PUBLIC REGARDING DOOR-TO-DOOR DISTRIBUTION OF REUSABLE MASKS

There are false text and audio messages circulating via text messaging services, claiming that there are people robbing residents under the pretext of distributing masks, purportedly under a new government initiative. The message also claimed that the residents would be made to try on masks believed to be doused with chemicals which made them lose consciousness.

This is untrue. The Police have not received any report regarding such incidents.

The Police urge the public not to spread unsubstantiated information which may cause public alarm.

The Police take a very stern view against anyone who knowingly spreads false information to mislead the public and will not hesitate to take actions against such individuals.

There are no government initiatives to distribute masks directly to households. Instead, all residents with registered home addresses will be able to collect reusable masks at designated Community Clubs/Centres and Residentsâ€™ Committees from 5 to 12 April 2020. Collection details are available on https://maskgowhere.sg.

#sgpoliceadvisory #sgpoliceclarify

Food and essential supplies will remain available, even when the latest safe distancing measures kick in on 7 April. The Goverment has assured that Singaporeans will still be able to meet their daily needs. #SGUnited

From 8th of April to 4th of May, schools and Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) will move to full Home-Based Learning. Preschool and student care centres will also suspend services.

Speaking at the Multi-Ministerial Taskforce press conference on 3rd of April 2020, Minister for Education, Ong Ye Kung added that this move will help enhance our safe distancing measure by significantly cutting down interactions to reduce further transmission of COVID-19.

General services for all pre-schools and student care centres will be suspended from 8 April to 4 May 2020. However, all subsidies for these services will continue to be disbursed during this period. Preschools will remain open for parents who work in essential services and are unable to find alternative caregiving arrangements.

Minister for Social and Family development, Desmond Lee, was speaking at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce press conference on 3 April 2020.

Minister for Manpower, Josephine Teo, reassured Singaporeans that enhancements will be made to the Job Support Scheme to help employers continue paying their workers. She added that waiving foreign worker levies is being considered, along with ensuring employers who need temporary help have the essential workforce to restart. She also encouraged employers to communicate clearly with their employees regarding work arrangements.

Minister for Trade and Industry, Chan Chun Sing shared that all residents can collect their reusable mask from the Community Centres (CCs) and Residentsâ€™ Committees (RCs) from Sunday, 5th April till the 12th of April 2020. He also added the there will be priority queues for seniors to collect their mask first. Singaporeans can refer to www.maskgowhere.sg on where and when to collect their mask.

He was speaking at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce press conference on 3 April 2020.

Speaking at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce press conference on 3 April 2020, Minister for National Development, Lawrence Wong reinforced that the significant tightening of measures does not mean that Singapore is shutting down its economy and all its services. Essential services will continue to be available to the community and Singaporeans can go out for essential needs.

He called for the cooperation of citizens as the government implements this new set of measures to limit the COVID-19 spread.

27 March 2020 at 23:34 Â·

[Rumour of Safe Distancing Ambassadors imposing fine]

There is a rumour circulating on social media and via text messaging platforms claiming that an Enterprise Singapore safe distancing ambassador had imposed a fine on an individual, for sitting on a seat that was marked out as not to be occupied.

This is FALSE.

Safe distancing ambassadors are deployed by various government agencies to guide and ensure that businesses implement and comply with the safe distancing measures. They do not impose fines.

Businesses that are found to have violated the Infectious Diseases Act and regulations promulgated thereunder may be liable for an offence and charged.

We advise members of the public to avoid spreading unverified information.

PSA: Take #safedistancing measures seriously.

Singapore Tourism Board
25 March 2020 at 05:02 Â·

[Joint statement by the Singapore Tourism Board, Enterprise Singapore and Singapore Police Force]

Following yesterdayâ€™s announcement that all entertainment venues will be closed from 26 March, 2359 hours till 30 April, we are aware a number of nightlife operators intend to host â€œfarewellâ€ events tonight that could result in large numbers of people congregating. These events undermine the fight against COVID-19 and increases risk to public health. If you are planning to attend, we urge you to seriously reconsider, if not for your own health, then for the health of those around you.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforceâ€™s decision to enforce stricter safe distancing measures aims to significantly reduce the risks of seeding new local COVID-19 clusters, which could strain our healthcare system further.

From now until the stricter measures kick in on 26 March 2020, 2359 hours, nightlife operators must continue to strictly implement safe distancing measures announced by the Ministry of Health on 20 March 2020. Events with 250 or more participants must be suspended, while operators of events with fewer than 250 participants must implement all necessary precautionary measures, including ensuring a distance of at least a metre between all participants and reduce mingling amongst participants.

These safe distancing measures are enforceable. Officers from government agencies including the Singapore Police Force will be on the ground to monitor the situation and carry out enforcement action over the next two days. The Traffic Police will also be conducting island-wide enforcement operations against drink-driving during this period. We will not hesitate to take action against anyone who fails to comply.

During this time, we appeal to Singaporeans to exercise good judgement and social responsibility. This will play an important part in keeping fellow Singaporeans and our loved ones safe in the midst of this global pandemic.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce on COVID-19 today announced stricter safe distancing measures to prevent further spread of the disease, especially among vulnerable segments of the population. This is in view of the pattern of transmission among the locally transmitted cases. Ministry of Health, Singapore found that the spread occurred during events at the workplace as well as social and religious gatherings. These safe distancing measures must be stepped up urgently in tandem with our parallel efforts to tighten our borders and to ring fence any infection clusters.

In line with the new measures, Muis will continue to work closely with our mosques to assess how we can operationalise safe distancing when our mosques open its doors to congregants next Friday, 27 March 2020.

The Fatwa committee will be consulted to guide us on the proposed adjustments that will need to be made to our prayer practices, in accordance with safe distancing requirements. More information will be available soon.

As the COVID-19 situation continues to evolve, I thank our community for your strong support and commitment to overcome this challenge together. I look forward to your understanding and strong support to ensure the safety of our mosques, our community and our fellow Singaporeans. Together, we can get through this!

Eggcellent news ğŸ¥šğŸ™Œ

Chan Chun Sing
19 March 2020 at 10:18 Â·

Was at Changi Airport this afternoon to receive a very special cargo - more than 300,000 eggs meant for domestic consumption.

About a quarter of the eggs we consume are produced locally and a significant number come from Malaysia. However, we also have many other source countries which we have identified over the years and are able to activate them quickly when the need calls for it. This applies not just to eggs but other food products and essential items.

We managed to activate this option in a matter of two days and I would like to express my appreciation to Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources (MEWR), the Singapore Food Agency (SFA), Singapore Airlines and SATS for helping us to bring the eggs in so quickly.

These efforts to secure and diversify our food supply have been developed and strengthened through the years. Even though we have a robust plan in place, we do not take it for granted and reassess it regularly to test its robustness against different scenarios. This is how things have always been done in Singapore and will continue to guide our approach to all issues, big and small, going forward. CCS

#SGUnited

Chan Chun Sing
15 March 2020 at 10:01 Â·

In order to further reduce the risk of importation of COVID-19 cases to Singapore, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce has announced additional border restriction measures.

From 16 March 2359 hours, all travellers entering Singapore with recent travel history to ASEAN countries, Japan, Switzerland or the United Kingdom within the last 14 days will be issued with a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN).

However, given our close proximity to Malaysia, the 14-day SHN will not apply to our land and sea crossings with Malaysia. Singaporean and Malaysian workers who commute between Singapore and Malaysia daily will still be able to do so. The latest restrictions will also not have an impact on the supply of food and other essentials between Singapore and Malaysia as drivers of goods vehicles will be able to enter as per normal.

These new measures are necessary to ensure that our healthcare system does not get overwhelmed by people entering Singapore for the sole purpose of seeking treatment in Singapore. We will continue to monitor the situation closely as it develops globally. CCS

Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis)
15 March 2020 at 03:15 Â·

Update to The Community: Day 3 of Mosque Closure

Assalamualaikum warahmatullahi wabarakatuh.

Last Thursday, Muis took the unprecedented step of closing our mosques for at least 5 days, to allow us to begin thoroughly disinfecting our mosques, as well as work with MOH to undertake contact tracing of the jemaah attending the large scale event in KL and their close contacts.

I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the communityâ€™s understanding for the need for the temporary closures of our beloved mosques and the adjustments and inconvenience we have had to bear as a result. This is a necessary precautionary measure, as we gather in mosques in large numbers every day, and especially so on Fridays.

I would like to add that we must take special care to protect our seniors in the community, as studies have shown that the mortality rate is much higher for those aged 60 and above who contract the virus.

Alhamdulillah, many Muslims have expressed support and understand it is our duty to protect the community and larger society.

MOH has since shared information that the infected individuals have been to 10 of our mosques since they returned from KL, and could have close contact with other jemaah in our mosques during this time when they were infectious. As such, we are issuing a public advisory with MOH to encourage persons who have been at the mosques during this time to take extra care and precaution.

The number of positive cases in Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei have also risen significantly over the past 2 days, among the returnees from the KL event.

In the last few days, there has also been news of some members of the community attending other large-scale religious gatherings overseas. We appeal to the community to avoid such events during this period.

In the meantime, the cleaning efforts in our mosques are proceeding smoothly. We are closely monitoring the developments, and will provide updates on the reopening of our mosques in due course.

Esa Masood
CE, Muis

Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, Masagos Zulkifli, emphasised the benefits of social norm adjustments, such as the use of serving spoons when sharing food as well as adopting the habit of eating from trays and returning trays after use to keep tables in public dining spaces clean.

There'll be more incentives to encourage Singaporeans to adopt cleaner vehicles, and an expansion of the public charging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 16:42 Â·

[Budget 2020: Managing our Carbon Constraints]

Our vision is to phase out ICE vehicles and have all vehicles run on cleaner energy by 2040. To promote this, we will have three measures in this Budget.

First, we will enhance incentives to encourage the adoption of cleaner and more environmentally friendly vehicles.

Second, we will expand the public charging infrastructure for EVs.

Third, the Government will take the lead. We will progressively procure and use cleaner vehicles to do our part for the environment.

Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources (MEWR)
Ministry of Transport, Singapore

#SGBudget2020

A new Enabling Employment Credit will provide stronger support for employers of persons with disabilities. It will be available from 2021 to 2025.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 16:36 Â·

[Budget 2020: Strengthening Our Giving Culture]

We want to build an inclusive society, where no one is left behind.

We will introduce the new Enabling Employment Credit (EEC) to provide stronger support for employers of persons with disabilities. It will be available for five years, from 2021 to 2025, at a cost of about $31 million per year.

To ensure that the EEC remains helpful for persons with disabilities to find employment and remain in the workforce, the Government will review the EEC after two years and make adjustments if necessary.

Ministry of Manpower - Mom will provide more details at the COS.

#SGBudget2020

A Matched Retirement Savings Scheme will be introduced from 2021 to 2025. All cash top-ups to an eligible Singaporeanâ€™s CPF account, regardless of the source of the contribution, will be eligible for the matched savings.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 16:36 Â·

[Budget 2020: Enabling our Seniors]

We will increase retirement support for seniors through three measures:

First, we will do more to help Singaporeans tap on their housing assets for retirement. Ministry of National Development will provide more details at the COS.

Second, we will introduce a Matched Retirement Savings Scheme from 2021 to 2025. This will help those who have less CPF savings to save more. All cash top-ups to an eligible Singaporeanâ€™s CPF account, regardless of the source of the contribution, will be eligible for the matched savings. Ministry of Manpower - Mom will provide more details at the COS.

Third, we will enhance the Silver Support Scheme to provide lower-income seniors with greater assistance for their retirement needs.

We will also provide top-ups of $750 million to the ElderCare Fund, $500 million to the ComCare Fund, and $200 million to the MediFund.

18 February 2020 at 16:17 Â·

There will be additional help for families taking care of children and elderly parents.

We will provide a further $100 cash payout for every adult Singaporean with at least one Singaporean child aged 20 years and below this year.

We will provide an additional GST Voucher â€“ U-Save rebate for larger households with five or more members, to help them with their utilities bills. Together with the U-Save Special Payment, larger households can receive a total of 2.5 times their regular U-Save rebates over the next year.

We will provide a $100 top-up to the PAssion Card to all Singaporeans aged 50 years and above, including Pioneer Generation and Merdeka Generation seniors.

More workfare for work done in 2019, and $100 grocery vouchers per year for 2020 and 2021.

18 February 2020 at 16:15 Â·

[Budget 2020: Care and Support Package for Households]

Lower-income Singaporeans will get additional help with their daily living expenses.

To further offset daily living expenses for lower-wage workers, we will provide a Workfare Special Payment. Singaporeans on Workfare will receive 20% more for work done in 2019, with a minimum payment of $100, given in cash.

More needy Singaporeans will also receive Groceries Vouchers worth $100 per year in 2020 and 2021, for use at major supermarkets.

18 February 2020 at 16:15 Â·

[Budget 2020: Care and Support Package for Households]

For Singaporeans ready to start a family and own a home, we will make sure that there is good access to quality and affordable housing.

To help all Singaporeans with their household expenses during this period of uncertainty, we will provide a Care and Support Package for households, amounting to about $1.6 billion.

i. All Singaporeans aged 21 and above in 2020 will receive a one off cash payout of $300, $200 or $100, depending on their income.

ii. We will double the amount of U-Save rebates through a one-off GST Voucher â€“ U-Save Special Payment to all eligible HDB households. This will help to free up cash for other household expenses.

iii. In addition, we will extend the Service and Conservancy Charges Rebate by another year. Eligible HDB households will receive rebates of between 1.5 to 3.5 months.

18 February 2020 at 16:12 Â·

[Budget 2020: Primary to Pre-University School Years]

For our youth in their Primary to Pre-University School years, we will:

-Enhance the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme by an additional $9 million per year. The annual bursary quantum for pre-university students will be raised from $900 to $1,000.
-Increase transport subsidies for all students, and school meals subsidies for secondary school students.

The Stabilisation and Support Package will help workers retain jobs and upgrade their skills, to be ready for when the tide turns.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 07:15 Â·

[Budget 2020: Stabilising and Supporting our Economy in the Near-Term]

Under the $4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package, we will help our workers retain their jobs, and use any lull period to upgrade their skills, to be ready when the tide turns. We will also help our enterprises to continue transforming, and make sure that their workers benefit.

To help our workers stay employed, we will support enterprises for a part of their wage cost, through introducing a Jobs Support Scheme and enhancing the Wage Credit Scheme.

Some sectors are more directly impacted, including tourism, air transport, as well as related sectors like retail, food services, and land transport.

To help employers in these sectors retain and reskill workers, we will enhance support under the Adapt and Grow initiative, specifically through redeployment programmes in affected sectors.

Taken together with the Jobs Support Scheme, we will support employers to retain and train more than 330,000 workers in these affected sectors. They can make full use of the down time for training and upskilling, to prepare for the recovery.

Ministry of Trade & Industry, Singapore Ministry of Manpower, Ministry of Transport, Singapore will share further details in due course.

#SGBudget2020

An additional $800 million will be set aside to support the fight and containment of COVID-19.

"Our immediate concern is to protect you and your families. We will put in every effort to slow down the spread of the virus." - DPM Heng, at Budget 2020.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 15:06 Â·

[Budget 2020: Dealing with the Immediate Challenges]

Our immediate concern is to protect you and your families. We will put in every effort to slow down the spread of the virus.

Frontline ministries have been fighting and containing the outbreak. We will set aside an additional $800 million in this Budget to support these efforts, with the bulk of this going to the Ministry of Health, Singapore.

With these uncertainties, Singaporeans are worried about the impact on our business and jobs. Families are also concerned about rising expenditures.

To stabilise the economy and provide assurance to Singaporeans, we will introduce two packages, totalling $5.6 billion.

The first is the Stabilisation and Support Package for workers and enterprises.

The second is the Care and Support Package for households, to support our people through these uncertain times, and alleviate concerns over cost of living. More help will be given to the less well-off.

#SGBudget2020

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2020 at 15:03 Â·

[Budget 2020: Responding to Challenges in a New Decade]

This year, we usher in a new decade â€“ one marked by tectonic shifts in our operating environment, and growing uncertainties.

Against this backdrop, Singaporeâ€™s economy grew by a modest 0.7% in 2019. This was the weakest growth since the 2008 Global Financial Crisis.

Just as the global economy was beginning to recover, the Coronavirus Disease 2019 or COVID-19 outbreak hit unexpectedly last month. This brings new uncertainties, felt across the world.

As an additional precautionary measure, Singapore residents and long-term pass holders returning from mainland China (outside Hubei) will be placed under a new "Stay-Home Notice" (SHN).

Under the SHN, returnees have to remain in their place of residence at all times during the 14-day period - making it stricter than the existing Leave of Absence (LOA) which allowed returnees to leave their homes briefly.

This was announced by Minister Lawrence Wong on 17 February 2020.

Doctors are to give 5-day medical certificates to patients with respiratory symptoms.

Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong explained that this is because a significant number of the confirmed cases have mild symptoms in the initial phase of the infection. Therefore, those with respiratory symptoms should rest and recover at home throughout their illness.

He was speaking at the Multi-Ministry Taskforce's press conference on 14 February 2020.

He also announced that Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs) will be re-activated to better detect and manage infections: https://facebook.com/watch/?v=1818018308335573

The government has no plan to go into DORSCON red.

At the Multi-Ministry Taskforce's press conference on 14 February 2020, Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong also explains that the PHPC clinics play an important role as the first line of defense.

There is no need to rush to buy essential supplies.

Let's play our part, exercise individual responsibility, and not hoard items unnecessarily.

Chan Chun Sing
7 February 2020 at 12:35 Â·

There have been many reports this evening of people buying up food and household items at our supermarkets. This has resulted in photos of temporary empty shelves in our supermarkets circulating on social media.

I understand that people are concerned after the announcement this afternoon that we have raised the DORSCON level to orange.

We have done so as there are now a few local cases without any links to previous cases or travel history to China. This is a scenario that we are prepared for and we will put in place additional measures to minimise the risk of further transmission.

MTI is in close contact with our retailers and I assure all Singaporeans that there is no need to rush for essential supplies like rice or instant noodles. Our supply lines for these essentials are intact and there is no risk of us running a shortage of essential food or household items. We also have our national stockpile for essential items.

However, we must all play our part, exercise individual responsibility and not hoard items unnecessarily. This will create undue panic and is unhelpful to the situation at hand.

Collective defence is our strongest defence. Let us all stay alert but remain calm and collected. The Government is monitoring all aspects of the situation closely and will always make sure that the needs of Singaporeans are met and catered for. CCS

At the press conference on 4 February 2020, Aubeck Kam, Permanent Secretary of Ministry of Manpower, elaborated that employers, workers and customers all have a part to play to prevent our frontline workers from being exposed to 2019-nCoV.

To enhance protection of students and staff against the 2019-nCoV, Director of Schools in Ministry of Education, Liew Wei Lin, announced additional measures in schools and preschools to minimise congregation of students in large numbers. These measures will be effective from 5 February 2020.

Minister for Health, Gan Kim Yong, confirmed 6 additional cases of 2019-nCoV infection in Singapore at a press conference on 4 February 2020. 2 of the cases were amongst those who were evacuated from Wuhan. Although 4 of the cases involved human-to-human transmission in Singapore, there is no evidence of community spread in Singapore.

There are a total of 24 cases in Singapore and one of the patients has been discharged.

Transmission is considered localised when authorities are able to identify and trace individual cases, and ring-fence a cluster to prevent the spread of infection. This is the situation for the cluster that has just been announced, said Professor Tan Chorh Chuan, Chief Health Scientist with the Ministry of Health, at the Multi-Ministry Taskforceâ€™s press conference on 4 February 2020. Prof. Tan was Singaporeâ€™s Director of Medical Services during the 2003 SARS outbreak.

As of 3 Feb 2020, the Ministry of Health has not been notified of any new confirmed cases of 2019 Novel Coronavirus (nCoV) in Singapore.

There is currently no evidence of community spread.

All of the previous cases remain in stable condition, and most are improving.

For more information, visit go.gov.sg/2019ncov

UPDATE ON THE 2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUS (nCoV) - FALSE RUMOURS:

There is a WhatsApp message circulating around with a list of alleged places to avoid where suspected or confirmed cases of the nCoV have been.

This is false. There is no need to avoid places where persons with suspected or confirmed cases of the nCoV have been.

The risk of infection from transient contact, such as in public places, is low. There is also currently no evidence of community spread.

For more information, refer to official sources such as the Ministry of Health's website (http://www.moh.gov.sg/) and Gov.sg (go.gov.sg/2019ncov).

Lawrence Wong
30 January 2020 at 06:21 Â·

<Masks for all Households; Use Responsibly>

We have sufficient masks in the national stockpile if everyone uses them responsibly. Responsible usage means following medical advice - only those who are sick need to wear masks; for those who are well, there is no need to wear masks.

Over the last 9 days, we released more than 5 million masks from the national stockpile to retailers. They were snapped up in hours. Yet many Singaporeans are still unable to get a mask. The current situation is clearly not sustainable.

This is why the Taskforce has decided to change our distribution method, as my colleague Chan Chun Sing and I announced this morning. First, we will prioritise the national stockpile of masks for essential services, namely our healthcare workers at the frontline. Second, for the general public we will release masks from the national stockpile directly to Singaporeans. In particular we will provide a packet of 4 masks each for every local household.

We are doing this to assure all Singaporeans that if any member of the family falls sick and needs a mask, they will have one at hand. But remember to use the masks responsibly. Do not wear the masks immediately. Keep this as a precaution and use the masks only if someone in the family falls sick and needs to go out to see the doctor.

I know many Singaporeans are concerned about the virus and want to protect themselves and their families. The best thing to do is to uphold good personal hygiene. Wash your hands regularly with soap; do not use your hands to touch your face; if you are sick, see a doctor and stay at home until you recover.

With individual and collective responsibility, we can maintain a strong defence against the virus, and overcome this together.

We welcome home today 92 Singaporeans who were stuck in Wuhan. Colleagues from MFA, CAAS, CAG, ICA and MOH worked hard to make this happen.

As we stand strong and united, we can get through this together, just as we have done before. ğŸ’ª

Khaw Boon Wan
30 January 2020 at 04:52 Â·

WELCOME HOME!

SCOOT TR121 from Wuhan which touched down this morning at Changi is special. It carried the 92 Singaporeans who were stuck in Wuhan when PRC decided to lock down the city. You can imagine their anxiety and fear! Their ordeal is over, though we have to put them under quarantine for 14 days.

TR121 was made possible through the dedication and sacrifice of many agencies and colleagues. We thank the MFA officers who gallantly escorted the Singaporeans back! We thank the CAAS, CAG, ICA and MOH colleagues who worked through the days and nights! We thank the SCOOT pilots and crew members who made this flight possible! On behalf of the MOT family, thank you to all of you!

As always, we stand together to help our fellow Singaporeans. This was what we did 17 years ago, when Singaporeans came together to battle SARS. With the experience from SARS, we started our thermal scanning much earlier this time at all our air, sea and land checkpoints.

We will conquer this Wuhan Virus, like how we did as a nation 17 years ago.

Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, Changi Airport Group, FlyScoot, Immigration & Checkpoints Authority, Ministry of Health, Singapore, Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs

Ministry of Health, Singapore
26 January 2020 at 00:28 Â·

As of 25 January 2020, 10pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed another imported case of Wuhan coronavirus infection in Singapore. Three confirmed cases were earlier announced on 23 and 24 January.

The fourth confirmed case is a 36 year-old male Chinese national from Wuhan who arrived in Singapore with his family on 22 January. He is currently warded in an isolation room at Sengkang General Hospital (SKH) and his condition is stable.

The case reported that he was asymptomatic during the flight to Singapore. He subsequently developed a cough on 23 January, and presented at SKH Emergency Department on 24 January. He was classified as a suspect case and immediately isolated. Subsequent test results confirmed Wuhan coronavirus infection at about 9.30pm on 25 January.

Prior to hospital admission, the case stayed at Village Hotel Sentosa.

MOH has initiated epidemiological investigations and contact tracing to identify individuals who had close contact with him.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/fourth-confirmed-imported-case-of-wuhan-coronavirus-infection-in-singapore

45 passionate Singaporeans came up with 9 ideas to improve household recycling in Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources (MEWR)'s #RecyleRight Citizens' Workgroup.ğŸ’¡Read on to find out more. #SGTogether

CHANNELNEWSASIA.COM
9 recycling ideas proposed at final session of citizens' workgroup | Video

Masagos Zulkifli
23 October 2019 at 12:19 Â·

This year Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources (MEWR) has embarked on several initiatives to seek the views of Singaporeans on environmental challenges and co-create solutions. This included consulting the public and key stakeholders on our Zero Waste Masterplan, and convening our inaugural Citizensâ€™ Workgroup to improve household recycling.

The Citizensâ€™ Workgroup initiative brought together citizens of diverse backgrounds, and allowed us to tap on the strengths and experiences of our community to develop interesting solutions. Over the past weekend, the #RecycleRight Citizens' Workgroup presented some of its final ideas to Senior Minister of State Amy Khor. I am heartened to learn of the participants' commitment to the Workgroup. Many of them met up several times outside of the official sessions to discuss their projects.

It has been a meaningful and rewarding experience for my colleagues at MEWR and National Environment Agency (NEA). We will continue to work together with Singaporeans on our journey #TowardsZeroWaste.

âš  Have you received a suspicious call from Infocomm Media Development Authority - IMDA asking for your name and NRIC, or your phone line will be terminated?

This is a scam call. Do not provide your personal information or transfer any money to the caller.

Infocomm Media Development Authority - IMDA
22 October 2019 at 06:07 Â·

[Public Advisory on Callers Impersonating IMDA Officers]

The IMDA is aware that some members of the public have received suspicious calls from persons claiming to be IMDA officers. The callers claim that the member of the publicâ€™s phone lines will be terminated, unless they provide their names and NRIC numbers to the caller.

These are scam calls. IMDA does not request for personal information such as NRIC details through unsolicited telephone calls.

Members of public who receive such calls should:
â€¢ Ignore the call. Members of public can call IMDA separately at 6377 3800 to verify suspicious calls involving IMDA officers.
â€¢ Do not provide personal information such as your name, identification number, passport, bank account, credit card details, and One-Time-Password (OTP).
â€¢ Do not transfer any money to the caller, either via remittance agencies, banks or any other means.

IMDA takes such incidents seriously as they undermine public trust in IMDA as a public agency and has alerted the Police of this incident.

If you have information related to such scams, please call the Police hotline: 1800 255 0000 or submit it online at www.police.gov.sg/iwitness. If you require urgent police assistance, please dial â€˜999â€™.

You may also call the anti-scam helpline at 1800-722-6688 or go to www.scamalert.sg to seek scam-related advice.

On 4 Oct, Terry Xu/The Online Citizen made a statement that there was a â€œHep C cover up prior to the GE2015â€. This is false.

https://facebook.com/154909330630/posts/10157378092575631/

#Factually

Ministry of Health, Singapore
7 October 2019 at 08:19 Â·

Terry Xuâ€™s/The Online Citizenâ€™s statement that there was a â€œHep C cover up prior to the GE2015â€ is false. An Independent Review Committee conducted an objective and critical review of the incident and found no evidence of deliberate delays by SGH or MOH in escalating the Hepatitis C outbreak, let alone a cover up. Public healthcare professionals and MOH officers carry out their duties professionally with patientsâ€™ best interests in mind. The timeline of key events was disclosed by MOH. Questions on the incident were raised in Parliament, to which the Minister for Health provided full responses.

â€œSama-sama maju ke hadapanâ€¦â€ words that almost every Singaporean would have sung at some point growing up. The song "Semoga Bahagia" was composed by one of Singapore's pioneering musical greats - Zubir Said. Despite his lack of a formal music education, he learnt how to play the flute, the guitar, the drums, the violin, the piano, and how to read and compose music. He wrote and composed our National Anthem, and over 1,500 other songs for films and popular listening.

Re-live your childhood with this music video and sing along to this rendition of Semoga Bahagia by local singer Imran Ajmain.

Last weekend, 58 Singaporeans from all walks of life came together for the inaugural Citizensâ€™ Panel on Work-Life Harmony.

Read on as Minister Josephine Teo shares how the Citizens' Panel brings together Singaporeans to discuss issues Singaporeans care about.

#SGTogether

Josephine Teo is in Singapore.
28 September 2019 at 12:00 Â· Singapore Â·

PARTNERING SINGAPOREANS, FOR SINGAPOREANS

58 Singaporeans came together for the first session of the Citizensâ€™ Panel on Work-Life Harmony today. It was initially intended to be a Panel of about 50 members, but due to the enthusiastic response from the public, we tried to accommodate more.

Everyone of us as citizens have an equal stake in Singapore. Everyone brings something different to the table. How do we make progress on the issues we care about? How can we shape a better future together? This is the essence of the SG Together movement, working with Singaporeans for Singaporeans. The Citizensâ€™ Panel is a relatively new way to foster such partnerships.

One area that Singaporeans care a lot about is families and we can achieve Work-Life Harmony. This is really about social norms â€“ what we say and do that is acceptable to each other. Itâ€™s an area where joint action by everyone in society is likely to produce better results.

Low Yen Ling, Assoc Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim and I, along with tripartite leaders, had a chance to interact with the Panel members, who come from all walks of life â€“ employers, employees, freelancers, homemakers, retirees. Despite the diverse backgrounds and perspectives, all of us want to make a difference, and collectively find a way forward for work-life harmony in Singapore. - Jo Teo

Ever wondered what the 36 year-old ROM building ğŸ‘°ğŸ¤µcould look like with a revamp? Keep a look out for new designs of the building done by students from SUTD, NP and TP at the #MyFutureROM exhibition!

MSF Singapore
21 August 2019 at 12:33 Â·

And...this iconic building is indeed the Registry of Civil and Muslim Marriages! It is also known as the ROM & ROMM building. Students from SUTD, NP and TP were asked to re-imagine what the 36 year-old building can be. Drawing on Singaporeans' memories of the building, as well as their own thoughts about marriage, our youths have proven their creative talents with their works of art!

Come check out 7 of the designs at the Designing #MyFutureROM exhibition, happening from 23 Aug - 20 Sep at the ROM & ROMM building at 7 Canning Rise! Give your support to our budding designers and tell them what you like about their designs!

You may have chanced upon a Facebook post by Ms Emily Boo (â€œMs Yukimi Wuâ€) saying that her father, Mr Boo Meng Hock, who has been missing for 23 years, continued to have his MediShield Life premiums deducted.

In line with industry practice, the CPFB (CPF Board) treats an individual as alive until they have been registered as deceased with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA). CPF records show that neither Ms Boo nor any of Mr Boo's family members have approached the CPFB for assistance on the continued deduction. CPF has reached out to her to explain steps to declare her father as deceased.

CPF.GOV.SG
Industry practice to treat person as alive till receipt of death certification from ICA

Be careful of fraudulent websites that spread false and misleading information. #Factually

Halimah Yacob
2 August 2019 at 20:05 Â·

There is a fraudulent website claiming that I have launched a new initiative to adopt blockchain technology and a new bitcoin trading system platform at a press conference. The site encourages the reader to sign up for their bitcoin platform and make a deposit via credit card or bank transfer.

The information listed on the website is false and misleading. The site had doctored an image of one of my Facebook posts at a dialogue to give the illusion that I had made these announcements, in order to solicit bitcoin investments.

I urge Singaporeans to be cautious when coming across such scams that ask for your financial and personal information.

Received a WhatsApp message that you can claim $2,800 from the Government? It's #fake.

Stay safe online and only use the official Government websites. #Factually

MOM.GOV.SG
Transact safely and securely

Singapore Ministry of Manpower
1 August 2019 at 14:08 Â·

The WhatsApp message saying that workers can claim $2,800 from the Government is fake. The message also contains a link to a fake MOM website - http:// bit. ly/ gov-sg (which redirects to http://6uio. com/sg/#).

Please use only the official MOM website at www.mom.gov.sg for all info and transactions on MOM matters. Here are tips on how to identify and report fake â€œMOMâ€ websites, phone calls and emails: www.mom.gov.sg/transact-safely-and-securely.

We will continue to monitor for fake â€œMOMâ€ websites and work to bring them down. We also remain committed to keeping the official MOM website unaffected and your data safe.

Comments that are uncalled for and unhelpful can stir up racial tensions. If you're unsure about a piece of news, don't spread. #notsuredontspread #spreadlovenothate #factually

Madrasah Al-Ma'arif Al-Islamiah
16 July 2019 at 13:36 Â·

It has come to our attention that a photo of our students has been circulated irresponsibly in the social media and speculations were made as to the nature of the interaction. We would like to make a clarification as to the true nature of the photo.

As part of the newly launched â€˜Riders on Watchâ€™ scheme, our students had been approached by Transcom, on their way to school this morning, to participate in this new initiative. The Riders on Watch scheme is an initiative where volunteers can sign up to be part of a team of commuters that will help to keep a lookout for suspicious items or characters, and alert the police so that a follow-up can be done (To find out more : https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/riders-on-watch-fight-crime-public-transport-transcom-11683474). We are proud of our studentsâ€™ sense of civic-mindedness and responsibility towards their community.

Thus, we are appalled at the irresponsible circulation of our studentsâ€™ photo which had been taken out of context. We would like to appeal to the public to help us in stopping further speculation or irresponsible circulation of the photo in order to respect the privacy of our students.

Thank you.

Interested to discuss solutions on work-life harmony with like-minded Singaporeans? Applications to join a Citizens' Panel are now open!ğŸ‘ªğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

Josephine Teo is at Grand Park City Hall, Singapore.
15 July 2019 at 07:21 Â· Singapore Â·

IMPROVING WORK-LIFE HARMONY, TOGETHER

Work and family responsibilities demand a lot of our time and energy. Many of us try to cope as best as we can.

It is therefore heartening whenever I learn of employers that have taken the effort to improve conditions for work-life harmony for its staff. I visited Grand Park City Hall, Singapore today and saw how they had measures in place to create a supportive environment for their staff, many of whom are working mothers and caregivers. All employees are given flexibility such as compressed work shifts, while non-frontline employees can also enjoy flexible start and end times. The hotel has even installed sleep capsules in the staffâ€™s lounge, for those who need to catch a quick nap to recharge!

I chatted with a few staff. They are appreciative of the flexible-work arrangements in place. Davina, a first-time mother, opted to start and end work earlier on Fridays, so that she can head home and spend time with her four-month-old daughter and family. Nurhida, a mother of two, is able to start and end work by 5:30pm during fasting month, to break fast with her family.

What more can be done to improve the conditions that support Work-Life Harmony?

As it is an issue thatâ€™s close to all our hearts, I believe it would be meaningful to involve fellow Singaporeans in developing recommendations that support Work-Life Harmony. The Citizensâ€™ Panel on Work-Life Harmony will be an opportunity for us to shape a new consensus on helping Singaporeans to manage both their work and family commitments. I am happy to announce that applications to be part of the Panel opened today.

If you are keen to work together with fellow Singaporeans to develop solutions that support work-life harmony in #Singapore, please visit http://www.ideas.gov.sg/public/CitizensPanel_WorkLifeHarmony to register your interest. From that link, you can also find out more about whatâ€™s required of a Panel member. We look forward to getting your views, and working together with you on this very important issue of Work-Life Harmony. â€“ Jo Teo

#Didyouknow that 1.7 million eligible Singaporeans will benefit from $1 billion in GST Vouchers and MediSave top-ups between July and November 2019?

Watch this video to find out more. #SGBudget2019

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
26 June 2019 at 17:24 Â·

1.7 million Singaporeans to benefit from $1 billion in GST Vouchers and MediSave Top-ups

Good news! If you are one of the 1.7 million eligible Singaporeans, you will receive a text message and/or letter on the various benefits under the GST Voucher (GSTV) scheme and/or Budget 2019 by 5 July 2019.

Alternatively, you can also view your GST Voucher (GSTV) benefits at www.gstvoucher.gov.sg, using your SingPass login.

In August, about 1.4 million Singaporeans will receive GSTV â€“ Cash of up to $300 each. About 520,000 Singaporeans aged 65 and above in 2019 will receive up to $450 in GSTV â€“ MediSave.

In November, the GSTV â€“ Cash recipients will each receive an additional cash payment of up to $300 as part of the Bicentennial Bonus.

About 930,000 eligible HDB households will receive a GSTV â€“ U-Save of up to $100 quarterly, as well as up to 3.5 months of S&CC rebates, depending on their flat type.

To find out more: https://www.mof.gov.sg/Newsroom/Press-Releases/1.7-million-singaporeans-to-benefit-from-1-billion-in-gst-vouchers-and-medisave-top-ups

Why are Singapore's official population statistics different from those released by international organisations? Read on to find out. #factually

Why are Singaporeâ€™s official population statistics different from those released by international organisations?

Singapore uses the de jure approach when counting our population

International organisations use the de facto approach when counting population

Do you have ideas on strengthening support for marriage and parenthood? Share your views at the following link: Heybaby.sg/PlayAPart ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘§â€ğŸ‘¦

Josephine Teo is in Singapore.
20 April 2019 at 09:33 Â· Singapore Â·

EMBRACING PARENTHOOD CELEBRATIONS

Being part of The People's Associationâ€™s Embracing PArenthoodcelebrations is always a lovely reminder of the joys of parenthood. Embracing PArenthood Celebrations is also a reminder that the community is behind every parent, and that we all want to see you succeed in your parenting journey.

I chatted with many couples and grandparents too. Daddies these days are very much more involved â€“ fantastic! Still, several third-time mothers left the biggest impression. One told me she was fortunate that even though she started late (after her PhD), she was able to conceive. Another already had two boys â€“ 6 and 8 years old â€“ but felt the need to spend more time with them. Hence, she moved to a job with more stable work hours. Although bonuses are smaller in her new role, she feels her life is more balanced and this also encouraged her to have a third child. There were two nurses â€“ one expectant mum who continues to work and is supported by her helper and mother, while another who stopped working full-time when her first-born was five. The latter decided to stay home partly because her husband travels a lot for his work. Although her three children keep her very busy, she intends to resume part-time work once her children start schooling.

Parenthood is hard work and it does involve sacrifice. But these women did not let it stop them, and are confident their careers can still grow. Of course, the support of their husbands, families, helpers and co-workers are also essential. So this morningâ€™s event was to let these families know the community celebrates with them. Also, we want to better support families.

We have been working on three main areas to better support marriage and parenthood - housing, preschool and community and workplace support. We need the help of Singaporeans to play a part, and provide us with your views so that we can work on things that make a difference to you.

Take the survey, and share your views with us at Heybaby.sg/PlayAPart, and I would like to encourage everyone, in your various roles as a family member, friend, employer, or co-worker, to join us in creating an environment that makes marriage and parenthood achievable, enjoyable and celebrated.

Letâ€™s all play a part in Making #Singapore a Great Place for Families! - Jo Teo

Saw some online allegations that Parking.sg costs...$30million? ğŸ¤”

Hear from the Parking.sg team on the actual fees that go into this time- and money-saving app ğŸš—ğŸš•ğŸ

#Factually

Parking.sg
19 March 2019 at 08:51 Â·

Some of you may be interested to hear how much it cost to develop and maintain parking.sg.

The project received a 4-year funding of $1.96 million in Feb 2017. By using modern cloud services, we are able to keep the cost low. For those of you who are interested, here are some services used in our production system and the rough monthly costs:
~$5000 a month for cloud hosting and databases
~$300 a month for a Content Delivery Network which also provides DNS and DDOS protection
~$200 a month for a service that automatically tests and deploys our code
~$100 a month for service monitoring and alerts
~$30 a month for Customer Relationship Management system to respond to your feedback
~$40 a month for database backups
~$25 a month for the informational site you see at parking.sg

Instead of hiring an external vendor, Parking.sg was built in-house by the project team themselves. Various people on the project team helped out, but at any point there were at most 3 people working full time on it. This saved us a lot of money since we didnâ€™t have extra project management overhead or procurement costs.

We are grateful for this opportunity to share more on the costing of the project and will share more when we open-source the project in the first half of this year. If you have any suggestions on how we can be more efficient, we would love to hear from you. â˜ºï¸

Some of you may be interested to hear how much it cost to develop and maintain parking.sg.

The project received a 4-year funding of $1.96 million in Feb 2017. By using modern cloud services, we are able to keep the cost low. For those of you who are interested, here are some services used in our production system and the rough monthly costs:
~$5000 a month for cloud hosting and databases
~$300 a month for a Content Delivery Network which also provides DNS and DDOS protection
~$200 a month for a service that automatically tests and deploys our code
~$100 a month for service monitoring and alerts
~$30 a month for Customer Relationship Management system to respond to your feedback
~$40 a month for database backups
~$25 a month for the informational site you see at parking.sg

Instead of hiring an external vendor, Parking.sg was built in-house by the project team themselves. Various people on the project team helped out, but at any point there were at most 3 people working full time on it. This saved us a lot of money since we didnâ€™t have extra project management overhead or procurement costs.

We are grateful for this opportunity to share more on the costing of the project and will share more when we open-source the project in the first half of this year. If you have any suggestions on how we can be more efficient, we would love to hear from you. â˜ºï¸

K Shanmugam Sc
15 March 2019 at 15:28 Â·

[ Massacre in #NewZealand ]

NZ is a peaceful country. Seen as a model of race relations.

Today it suffered a horrific massacre of 49 innocent persons.

Carried out by a white man, ( apparently an Australian ) targeting Muslims in a mosque, in Christchurch.

He live-streamed his murderous assault.

He released an extreme, violent message just before his attack. He and two others have apparently been arrested.

Most people cannot imagine this happening in NZ.

Our prayers are with the victims and their families. It is heart breaking that people, praying in a mosque, should be mowed down.

Hours later, an Australian Senator, issued an Islamophobic Statement, describing Islam as a violent, fascist religion, and said it promoted savage beliefs. He also attacked the Prophet, and blamed Muslim immigration, for the massacre.

The Senatorâ€™s Statement is sickening. It is completely unacceptable. And he issued it when people are grieving.

In some parts of the world, there is open Islamophobia. Very sad.

11 March 2019 at 21:15 Â·

Since 2013, the Better Internet Campaign by the Media Literacy Council has been promoting the safe and responsible use of digital technology. At the inaugural Better Internet Conference today, I launched this yearâ€™s Better Internet Campaign with the catchy tagline â€“ â€œBe Safe, Be Smart and Be Kind!â€ This tagline captures the key instincts we all need to nurture in the digital age: to be respectful in our online discourse, to be cautious in our online habits and to evaluate the veracity of the information we come across.

We can all be our very own best defenders against online falsehoods, when we arm ourselves with the knowledge and skills to do so. And this need not be difficult, especially when we come together as a nation â€“ individuals, industry, government and community, to help one another be the best online defender that we can be!

Take a look at these mouth-watering edible works of art! Not only are they yummy, they are also free from artificial colourings and preservatives!

Miss Tam Chiak interviews the mother-daughter pair behind Kueh Ho Jiak â€“ the creator of these insta-worthy ang ku kueh made using traditional wooden mouldings with unique fillings to attract younger customers.

LIKE this post to pledge your support for Singaporeâ€™s UNESCO bid for #ourhawkerculture! Also pledge your support at www.oursgheritage.sg.

Miss Tam Chiak posted a video to the playlist Hawkers â€” at Kueh Ho Jiak
22 February 2019 at 08:11 Â· Singapore Â·

Make a guess what these are? One look and you might think that they are artsy pendants, but these are ang ku kuehs that you can find in a hawker centre!

At Kueh Ho Jiak, the traditional ang ku kueh is given a makeover by young hawker Elizabeth and her mother. The mother and daughter duo did not come from a line of hawkers, they had to start from scratch. They went to learn the technicalities of the craft and tweaked them on the fly.

There is just so much love and passion poured into these handmade kuehs. Kueh Ho Jiak keeps the tradition alive and tweaked their craft to keep things relevant with the times. Read more: https://www.misstamchiak.com/kueh-ho-jiak-hawker-heritage/

Did the CPF Board change the â€œretirement payout ageâ€ to 70 years old?

No, there is no change. It is 65 years old.

As CPF members, you decide when is the best time to start your retirement payouts, as you are in the best position to decide based on your individual circumstances.

Read on as #Factually summarises what you need to know.

The Payout Eligibility Age is 65. There is no change

You decide when to activate your payouts anytime between 65 and 70

3 simple ways to apply for your CPF payouts

Your payouts will start automatically at age 70 if you do not apply

You can get more if you decide to start later

When it comes to Singapore's overall taxes and transfers system, the Government will ensure that it will always remain fair, progressive, and pro-growth.

#SGBudget2019

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 17:29 Â·

[GST]

When the GST is raised sometime from 2021 to 2025, the Government will continue to absorb GST on publicly subsidised education and healthcare. The Government will provide more help to lower-income households and the elderly by enhancing the permanent GST Voucher scheme.

The Government will also cushion the GST increase for a period through a GST offset package. Lower-income and middle-income households will receive more.

More details will be announced later.

#SGBudget2019

#SGBudget2019: GST import relief for travellers will be reduced. The Alcohol duty-free allowance will also be reduced from 1 April.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 17:28 Â·

[GST Import Relief for travellers]

The Government will tighten the GST import relief for travellers. For travellers who spend less than 48 hours outside Singapore, the relief limit will be reduced from $150 to $100. For 48 hours or more, the relief quantum will be reduced from $600 to $500. This will take effect from tomorrow.

The alcohol duty-free concession for travellers will be tightened from three litres to two litres from 1 April.

#SGBudget2019

Singapore Customs

The excise duty for diesel will be raised, while the annual special tax on diesel cars and taxis will be reduced. #SGBudget2019

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 17:20 Â·

[Diesel Taxes]

Diesel exhaust is highly pollutive, and adversely affects our health and quality of life. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has classified diesel exhaust as carcinogenic.

The Government will raise the excise duty for diesel by $0.10 per litre, to $0.20 per litre. At the same time, the annual Special Tax on diesel cars and taxis will be permanently reduced by $100 and $850 respectively. Road tax rebates will be provided to cushion the impact for commercial diesel vehicles, and additional cash rebates will be provided for diesel buses ferrying school children.

#SGBudget2019

#SGBudget2019 - Bicentennial Bonus includes:

1. Up to $300 GST Voucher-Cash to lower-income Singaporeans

2. CPF top-up of up to $1,000 for Singaporeans aged 50 to 64 who have less than $60,000 in their CPF accounts

3. $150 top-up to Edusave accounts for primary and secondary school students

4. Students aged 17-20 will receive up to $500 in their Post-Secondary Education Accounts

5. 50% personal income tax rebate (subject to $200 cap) for personal income taxpayers

The Government will also provide another year of Service and Conservancy Charges (S&CC) rebate, and will top up the Public Transport Fund by $10 million.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 09:11 Â·

[Commemorating Our Bicentennial]

$200 million will be set aside for a Bicentennial Community Fund which will provide dollar-for-dollar matching for donations made to all Institutions of a Public Character (IPCs) in FY2019.

$1.1 billion will also be set aside as a Bicentennial Bonus to Singaporeans to commemorate this significant moment in Singaporeâ€™s history.

As part of the Bicentennial Bonus, lower-income Singaporeans will receive up to $300 through a GST Voucher â€“ Cash (Bicentennial Payment); those who received WIS payments will get a Workfare Bicentennial Bonus amounting to an additional 10% of their WIS payment for work done in 2018.

Personal income taxpayers can look forward to a 50% personal income tax rebate, subject to a cap of $200, for the Year of Assessment 2019.

Parents with children in schools can look out for a $150 top-up to the Edusave accounts of their children in primary and secondary school. Those who are aged 17 to 20 will also receive up to $500 in their Post-Secondary Education Accounts (PSEA).

Older Singaporeans aged 50 to 64 who have less than $60,000 in their CPF accounts will receive CPF top-up of up to $1,000.

Besides the Bicentennial Bonus, the Government will also provide another year of Service and Conservancy Charges (S&CC) rebate.

The Public Transport Fund will also be topped up by $10 million.

#SGBudget2019
#BicentennialBonus

Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth - MCCY
Singapore Ministry of Manpower
Ministry of Education, Singapore
CPF Board

#SGBudget2019: The Merdeka Generation Package (MGP) will cover:

1. $100 PAssion Silver Card top-up

2. $200/year MediSave top-ups until 2023

3. Additional subsidies for outpatient care

4. Additional MediShield Life premium subsidies, for life

5. $1,500 CareShield Life participation incentive

Find out more at www.merdekageneration.sg

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 08:54 Â·

[Merdeka Generation Package]

#SGBudget2019 introduces the Merdeka Generation Package (#MGP) as a gesture of our nationâ€™s gratitude for the Merdeka Generationâ€™s contributions, and a way to show care for them in their silver years. It supports them in staying active and healthy, while providing grater peace of mind over future healthcare costs, for the Merdeka Generation and their families.

There will be 5 key benefits in the #MGP.

1) One-time $100 top-up to their PAssion Silver cards to support their active lifestyles.

2) MediSave top-up of $200 per year for five years, starting this year until 2023.

3) Additional subsidies for outpatient treatment, for life.

- Special CHAS subsidies at CHAS GPs and dental clinics.
- Additional 25% off subsidised bills at Polyclinics and public Specialist Outpatient Clinics (SOCs).

4) Additional MediShield Life premium subsidies, for life. This will start from 5% of their MediShield Life premiums, and increase to 10% after they reach 75 years of age.

5) Additional participation incentive of $1,500 to join CareShield Life, when it becomes available for existing cohorts in 2021.

Ministry of Health, Singapore

CHAS subsidies will be enhanced at GP clinics in three ways. A new Long-Term Care Support Fund will also help fund CareShield Life subsidies and ElderFund, said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, at #SGBudget2019.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 16:49 Â·

[Greater Healthcare Assurance]

As more Singaporeans enter their senior years, healthcare needs will grow. Major changes have been made in healthcare to make it more affordable, accessible, and comprehensive.

Looking ahead, CHAS subsidies for GP clinics will be enhanced in three ways.
- First, CHAS will be extended to cover all Singaporeans for chronic conditions, regardless of income.
- Second, lower to middle-income Singaporeans who are CHAS Orange cardholders will also receive subsidies for common illnesses.
- Third, there will be increased subsidies for complex chronic conditions.

The Government will put $5.1 billion into a new Long-Term Care Support Fund, which will help fund the CareShield Life subsidies as well as other long-term care support measures, such as ElderFund.

#SGBudget2019

Ministry of Health, Singapore

#SGBudget2019: Here's how we are spending more to support our young families, lower-wage workers, as well as older workers.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 08:42 Â·

[Uplifting Every Singaporean]

For young Singaporeans, we invest heavily to provide a world-class education to bring out their best, regardless of starting point. We are spending more to enhance the accessibility, affordability, and quality of early childhood care and education.

This support continues throughout the schooling years, with the Government subsidising more than 90% of the total cost of education. Children from disadvantaged backgrounds get even more support through schemes such as KidSTART.

For the bottom 20 per cent of workers, the WIS scheme will be enhanced to provide better support.
- From January 2020, the qualifying income cap will be raised from the current $2,000 to $2,300 per month.
- The maximum annual pay-outs will also be increased by up to $400.

For older workers, we are doing more to help them earn more, save more, and have greater peace of mind in their retirement years. The Government will review the relevance and structure of the Special Employment Credit (SEC) and the Additional Special Employment Credit (ASEC). The SEC and ASEC will be extended another year, until the end of 2020.

#SGBudget2019

Ministry of Education, Singapore
Singapore Ministry of Manpower

The Career Support Programme will be extended for two years, announced Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat at #SGBudget2019.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 16:07 Â·

[Deepening Workersâ€™ Capabilities By Helping Our People Seize Opportunities]

Our ultimate goal is to enable our people to continue to have good jobs and opportunities, and to be at their best. To achieve this, the Government will continue to invest in our people across all stages of their lives.

Workers, firms, unions, and TACs also need to play a part to continue this progress by embracing upskilling and reskilling, and stepping up training and job redesign for workers.

To continue to enable our experienced professionals to build on their experience to move into new growth areas, we will launch new conversion programmes to prepare our people to move into new growth areas. We will also extend the Career Support Programme for two years.

#SGBudget2019

Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighted that the Industry Transformation Maps drive transformation at the company, industry and economy-wide levels. #SGBudget2019 will focus on 3 key areas to further support industry transformation.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 15:48 Â·

[Strengthening Singaporeâ€™s Economic Competitiveness]

Over the years, sound monetary and fiscal policies have enabled us to weather global economic crises and keep inflation stable.

Besides maintaining a stable environment for investors to make long-term investment decisions, we need to undertake structural reforms, to enable our workers and firms to adapt and stay competitive.

Our transformation efforts through the Industry Transformation Maps have contributed to better productivity growth.

Our journey continues, and we must press on.

#SGBudget2019 will focus on 3 key areas to support industry transformation:

a) Building deep enterprise capabilities;

b) Building deep worker capabilities; and

c) Encouraging strong partnerships, within Singapore and across the world

Our economy grew by 3.2% in 2018, and real median income of Singaporeans has grown 3.6% per year over the past five years. #SGBudget2019

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 15:45 Â·

[Steady Growth in 2018 Amidst Challenges]

Our efforts to transform the economy are bearing fruit.

Singaporeâ€™s economy grew by 3.2% in 2018, and real median income of Singaporeans has grown by 3.6% per year over the past five years.

However, global growth is expected to moderate in 2019 with increased uncertainties and downside risks.

#SGBudget2019

Ministry of Trade & Industry

We must continue to innovate and build new capabilities to meet our security needs, said Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat at #SGBudget2019.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 15:45 Â·

[#SGBudget2019: Keeping Singapore Safe And Secure From Evolving Threats]

Today, security threats are evolving and becoming more complex. Besides the continuously high terrorism threat, malicious cyber activities are also growing.

To stay ahead of these threats, we must continue to innovate and build new capabilities to meet our security needs. Ministry of Home Affairs, Singapore will set up a Home Team Science & Technology agency this year, and help to transform the private security industry through innovation and technology.

Singaporeans must stay united and play our part in Total Defence, including Digital Defence, to keep Singapore safe and secure from both physical and digital threats.

The Government will continue to invest about 30% of our total expenditure this year to support our defence, security and diplomacy efforts. This consistent spending is significant, but indispensable.

Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF)

Our commitment to security and defence cannot waver, said Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat, at #SGBudget2019.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 15:39 Â·

[#SGBudget2019: Keeping Singapore Safe And Secure From Physical Threats]

A safe and secure Singapore is fundamental to continued economic success, and deterrence and diplomacy are the twin pillars of our approach.

We build good relations with other countries, to promote a rules-based international order with international laws and norms.

The SAF lends weight to our diplomatic efforts and ensures that negotiations with Singapore are taken seriously. The Home Team ensures a safe environment for all, while the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore protects us from cyber threats.

Against an increasingly uncertain geopolitical environment, our commitment to security and defence cannot waver.

Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF)
Ministry of Home Affairs, Singapore

In his Budget Speech, Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat said #SGBudget2019 is a strategic plan to build a Strong and United Singapore.

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
18 February 2019 at 15:38 Â·

[Our Strengths and Singapore DNA]

The changing global and domestic landscape presents both challenges and opportunities. We will chart our way forward the Singapore way â€“ with our openness, multi-culturalism, and self-determination.

#SGBudget2019 is a strategic plan to build a Strong, United Singapore. We will:
- Keep Singapore safe and secure;
- Continue to transform our economy;
- Build a caring and inclusive society;
- Build a globally connected, smart and sustainable global city and home for all; and
- Do this in a responsible and fiscally-sustainable manner.

#SGBudget2019
