A collision took place in Singapore Territorial Waters on 9 February - it was an accident, not 'arranged'. Do not believe any deliberate online falsehoods.

#Factually

Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore - MPA
11 February 2019 at 18:40 Â·

#ICYMI There have been false online allegations about the collision between PIREAS and POLARIS on 9 Feb 2019.

Here are the facts:
1428hrs: PIREAS collided with POLARIS on its way from Singapore to Tanjung Pelepas. The incident was witnessed by PCG patrolling in the vicinity. PIREAS also reported its collision with POLARIS to MPAâ€™s Port Operations Control Centre, and indicated that it had not sustained any damage.

1902hrs: After the facts had been established, MPA released a media statement, along with a photo of the incident.

1903hrs: The Straits Times posted the statement and carried the picture on its online site. It then followed up with a Facebook post at 1907hrs.

2000hrs: Videos of the collision were provided to the media.

As you can see, there is neither a â€˜chief culpritâ€™ nor an â€˜arrangedâ€™ incident. MPA is investigating, and strongly urges the public to avoid spreading deliberate online falsehoods.

Read the MPA statements here:
https://bit.ly/2RRtVt5, https://bit.ly/2SIaVlj

More than 500 guests attended the Merdeka Generation Tribute Event yesterday. Hosted by Prime Minister Lee, the lunch reception was held to thank our Merdeka Generation for their contribution throughout Singaporeâ€™s formative years.

They were treated to performances by artistes - Dick Lee, Rahimah Rahim, Mel Ferdinand and Jacintha Abisheganaden, who are also Merdeka Generation members. It was a day to catch up with old friends (and make new ones) and reminisce the days when they worked to shape our nation.

Struggle, sacrifice and survival: these defined the Merdeka Generationâ€™s journey in shaping our nation.

For building a better tomorrow for future generations, thank you.

Thank a Merdeka Generation senior who has inspired you today.

For more information, visit https://www.merdekageneration.sg/

Lee Hsien Loong
31 January 2019 at 20:57 Â·

Here is my speech launching the Singapore Bicentennial on Monday. I explained why 1819 was a crucial turning point in our history, and why our bicentennial is worth commemorating.

We became an independent republic in 1965, but our history stretches back much longer. Without that broader historical experience, 1965 would not have happened, and Singapore today would certainly be a very different place. â€“ LHL

Singapore ranks 2nd out of 140 economies in the World Economic Forumâ€™s Global Competitiveness Report and GDP is expected to grow by between 3.0% and 3.5% in 2018.

How else has the Government has performed in key areas like healthcare and security?

Find out more at https://www.mof.gov.sg/â€¦/defaulâ€¦/spor-2018/pdf/SPOR_2018.pdf

Ministry of Finance (Singapore)
20 December 2018 at 09:27 Â·

Do you recall how the Government has supported Singaporeans in the last few years?

The details can be found in the latest Singapore Public Sector Outcomes Review, or SPOR. Published by the Ministry of Finance every two years, the Report is produced in collaboration with various agencies, and serves as Singaporeâ€™s â€œreport cardâ€, tracking the Governmentâ€™s efforts in key areas, such as healthcare, transport, education, the economy, and national security.

#SPOR2018 provides an update on how the Government has performed through relevant indicators, such as the World Economic Forumâ€™s Global Competitiveness Report, the workforceâ€™s training participation rate, and the accessibility and affordability of healthcare services and housing.

Despite continuing global economic uncertainties, Singaporeâ€™s GDP is expected to grow by between 3.0% and 3.5% in 2018. Productivity in terms of real value added per actual hour worked has increased by over 3% from 2013 to 2017, and Singaporeansâ€™ wages have also increased.

To learn more about the various government schemes and programmes out there, click here: https://www.mof.gov.sg/docs/default-source/default-document-library/spor-2018/pdf/SPOR_2018.pdf

How does our nation ensure food security?

By not putting all of our eggs in one basket.

Lawrence Wong
13 December 2018 at 16:35 Â·

Singapore imports most of our food. They come from diverse sources - 180 countries around the world.

Our Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) officers inspect these overseas farms and accredit them for food safety; and our importers ensure that the food comes in safely through a reliable supply chain.

Our own farms are also producing more food within Singapore. Many are adopting new techniques to increase their production and yield.

All this means that we always have a range of options to ensure safe, quality and resilient food supply for Singaporeans.

Dear e-scooties in Singapore, fyip ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ›´

Land Transport Authority â€“ We Keep Your World Moving
12 December 2018 at 15:14 Â·

Do you own an #escooter in Singapore? ğŸ›´All e-scooters must comply with existing device criteria and be registered by 30 June 2019. From 2 January to 31 March 2019, users (above 16 years old) can register their devices for *FREE* online (More info: http://bit.ly/2EiTf89) or at any SingPost Post Office island-wide.

Upon successful registration, compliant e-scooters will be issued with an LTA Registration Mark bearing a unique registration number. Owners must affix the LTA Registration Mark, together with a separate Identification Mark onto their devices, within 14 calendar days of registration.

#Didyouknow? From 1 July 2019: It will be illegal to ride or permit another user to ride an unregistered e-scooter on public paths. Retailers will also be disallowed from selling motorised #PMDs that do not meet the #UL2272 fire safety standard â€“ aimed at minimising the risk of PMD-related fire incidents. Users with non-UL2272 certified e-scooters bought before 1 July can register and use these devices only up till 31 December 2020. Scoot to key dates for e-scooter registration below!
